repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
to be consistent with the behaviour of CyFunctions.

```
 # cython: binding=True
def f(arg):
  pass

class C:  # or cdef class...
  f = f
  def g(self, ...):
    pass

C.f(something) or C().f() # doesn't enforce any checks on the type of arg -
 # with a fused function it does.

C.g(something) # assumes that self is "C" (at least for a cdef class)
 # but doesn't check it. A fused function enforces that it is C.

C.f() # fails with a fused function claiming too few arguments, even though
 # default arguments may make it a valid call
```

Obviously removing checks does make things a little less safe, but it
is consistent with the more general function behaviour. (I'm doing
this as part of a broad plan to abuse fused functions to be a bit
cleverer about decorators, but I don't think the motivation hugely
matters for this change)

comment_data.body: Please keep the code C89 compatible.
This seems redundant. Just remove the first incref above.

Could you please also add the equivalent tests for Python functions and methods, by implementing the same thing in the doctests again? That way, we can be sure that all three function types really behave the same, not just the Cython implemented ones.

Alternatively, you can also change the test into a `.py` file and use pure Python declarations for the whole thing, so that the test runner will test it with both Python and Cython. That usually reduces the risk of incomplete test additions later.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,119 @@
+# mode: run
+# cython: binding=True
+
+"""
+Test that fused functions can be used in the same way as CyFunctions with respect to
+assigning them to class attributes. Previously they enforced extra type/argument checks

comment_data.body:
I've added equivalent tests to show that this is doing the same as Python.

Unfortunately writing it in pure Python mode doesn't seem possible at the moment - see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3142 (I get the same error using `@cython.locals` or annotations to set a fused type)

comment_data.body:
This looks like something that I fixed fairly recently https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3391 but the branch I'm using for this PR is now a bit old and doesn't have that merged in. I'll have another go.

I suspect that accidently closes the linked issue too (not completely sure though)

commit.message:
Relaxed some of the checks of fused functions

to be consistent with general CyFunctions.

```
 # cython: binding=True
def f(arg):
  pass

class C:  # or cdef class...
  f = f
  def g(self, ...):
    pass

C.f(something) or C().f() # doesn't enforce any checks on the type of arg -
 # with a fused function it does.

C.g(something) # assumes that self is "C" (at least for a cdef class)
 # but doesn't check it. A fused function enforces that it is C.

C.f() # fails with a fused function claiming too few arguments, even though
 # default arguments may make it a valid call
```

Obviously removing checks does make things a little less safe, but it
is consistent with the more general function behaviour. (I'm doing
this as part of a broad plan to abuse fused functions to be a bit
cleverer about decorators, but I don't think the motivation hugely
matters for this change)

Fixed version-sensitivity of doctests

A few things work differently on Python 2 (so omit them).
Some of the TypeError formatting changes around Python3.6 so just
accept any TypeError

Showing equivalence to Python behaviour

(+ small tidy-up from review)

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Relaxed some of the checks on calling fused functions
